data: Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is a defect in carbohydrate metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B (in the liver, kidney cortex, and small intestine). This means patients with HFI cannot break down fructose. Ingestion can lead to severe metabolic decompensation. HFI is treated by eliminating all sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from diet and medications.    SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, pallor, lethargy, coma and/or seizures. Laboratory findings: Rapid decrease, first of serum phosphate and then of blood glucose, urate and magnesium increase, liver enzymes increase, renal tubulopathy, and/or development of metabolic acidosis.     If untreated chronic manifestations include failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, jaundice, bleeding tendency, ascities, proximal renal tubulopathy

This patient cannot have any fructose, sucrose or sorbitol. Do NOT give fruit juice, fruits, vegetables, honey, table sugar, sugar alcohols, syrups or popsicles. Fructose, sucrose, and/or sorbitol are found in many processed foods, beverages, and medications. Patient may have normal home diet
Consult pharmacist to review medications to ensure fructose, sucrose and/or sorbitol containing medications are not ordered

This patient cannot have any fructose, sorbitol or sucrose. These sugars are in fruits, vegetables, honey, table sugar, sugar alcohol, syrups, processed foods, beverages, medications and some infant formulas.
